ground_truth: He turns to see an extremely pretty young woman gazing adoringly at him while they are jostled and shoved, and his eyes light up. Jurek pushes in beside them and takes her arm, pulling Dorota as he fights his way down the stairs, and he too is carried with the flow into the lobby where debris is everywhere. Szpilman fights to get to the main door when another bomb explodes, filling the air with dust and debris, obscuring him and everyone else. The Szpilman family is in panic, coming and going out of rooms, packing clothes and belongings into open suitcases and a trunk in a comfortable, tastefully furnished bourgeois apartment, the living room lined with books, paintings, and boasting a boudoir grand, silver platters, and candlesticks. Szpilman sits by the radio set, ear to the speaker, trying to tune to a station, while Father, holding a silver-framed photograph, crosses to Mother. He goes into his room as she can barely control her tears and hurries into the kitchen just as the front door opens and Szpilman enters, looking around bemused by the activity. Mother dashes out of the kitchen and starts to look as the others continue to bustle and pack. They gather round, and Henryk hits the set. Father pours liqueur into glasses, and the family is seated around the dining table, having just finished a meal, the table groaning with the remains. They all clink glasses and drink. A column of German soldiers, led by an officer on horseback, marches into view. On the sidewalk of the street, with its buildings in ruins and smoke still rising, stand onlookers, including Szpilman and Henryk, with Father craning to see. They watch expressionless as the Germans march past. Regina is opening and closing the window, examining the frame with her fingers, while at the other end, Father sits counting a small stack of notes and coins. Henryk is deep in thought, and Szpilman is fiddling with his father's violin. The apartment has less furniture now and the silver is gone. They all look at the table: it's covered in stains, and the veneer is coming away at one end until it snaps, revealing bare wood beneath. They start to hide the things. Szpilman is on the public telephone, waiting for someone to answer his call. Szpilman and Dorota stroll along a tree-lined street with bombed-out buildings and rubble. She flicks admiring, almost loving glances at him as they walk and talk, and he is smiling, touched by her. She's embarrassed and begins to laugh, and they become almost helpless, holding on to each other. Amidst their laughter, he takes her hand and kisses it. The family is gathered around the table, listening to Father reading from the newspaper.

His eyes light up with recognition and delight. Jurek, determined and forceful, pushes his way in beside them and takes hold of her arm, pulling Dorota along as he struggles to make his way down the crowded stairs. The Szpilman family is in a state of panic, moving in and out of rooms, hurriedly packing clothes and personal belongings into open suitcases and a large trunk within their comfortable, tastefully furnished bourgeois apartment. The living room is lined with books and paintings, boasting a boudoir grand piano, silver platters, and elegant candlesticks. Szpilman sits intently by the radio set, his ear pressed close to the speaker, trying to tune in to a station, while Father, holding a silver-framed photograph, crosses over to Mother. He retreats into his room as she struggles to control her tears and rushes into the kitchen just as the front door opens and Szpilman enters, looking around, bemused by the flurry of activity. Mother dashes out of the kitchen and begins to search as the others continue bustling and packing. They gather around, and Henryk gives the set a firm hit. Father pours liqueur into glasses, and the family is seated around the dining table, having just finished a meal, the table groaning under the weight of the remains. They all clink their glasses together and drink. A column of German soldiers, led by an officer on horseback, marches into view. On the sidewalk of the street, with its buildings in ruins and smoke still rising, stand onlookers, including Szpilman and Henryk, with Father craning his neck to see. They watch, expressionless, as the Germans march past. Regina is opening and closing the window, examining the frame with her fingers, while at the other end of the room, Father sits counting a small stack of notes and coins. Henryk is deep in thought, and Szpilman is fiddling with his father's violin. The apartment now has noticeably less furniture, and the silver is gone. They all look at the table: it's covered in stains, and the veneer is peeling away at one end until it snaps, revealing the bare wood beneath. They begin to hide their remaining possessions. Szpilman is at the public telephone, waiting patiently for someone to answer his call. Szpilman and Dorota stroll leisurely along a tree-lined street, surrounded by bombed-out buildings and rubble. She casts admiring, almost loving glances at him as they walk and talk, and he smiles, touched by her attention. She becomes embarrassed and starts to laugh, and they find themselves almost helpless with laughter, holding on to each other for support. Amidst their shared laughter, he gently takes her hand and kisses it. The family is gathered around the table, listening intently to Father as he reads aloud from the newspaper.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: As he gradually turns his head to look around, he notices an exceptionally stunning young woman gazing intently at him, her eyes filled with an intense adoration, even as they both find themselves being jostled and shoved by the dense crowd surrounding them. His eyes light up with an unmistakable sense of recognition and delight. In that moment, Jurek, who is both determined and forceful, pushes his way through the throng and positions himself beside them, firmly taking hold of her arm, pulling Dorota along with him as he struggles to make his way down the crowded and chaotic stairs. He, too, is eventually swept along with the relentless flow of people into the bustling lobby, which is littered with debris scattered haphazardly everywhere. Szpilman fights desperately, trying to reach the main door when, out of nowhere, another bomb detonates, sending a cloud of dust and debris swirling into the air, effectively obscuring his vision and that of everyone else around him. The Szpilman family is in a state of complete panic, moving frantically in and out of rooms, hurriedly packing clothes and personal belongings into open suitcases and a large trunk within their comfortable, tastefully furnished bourgeois apartment. The living room, lined with an array of books and paintings, boasts a grand boudoir piano, shiny silver platters, and elegant candlesticks. Szpilman sits intently by the radio set, his ear pressed close to the speaker, as he tries to tune in to a station, while Father, holding a silver-framed photograph, crosses over to Mother. He retreats into his room as she struggles to control her tears and rushes into the kitchen just as the front door opens and Szpilman enters, looking around, utterly bemused by the flurry of activity. Mother dashes out of the kitchen and begins to search as the others continue bustling and packing hurriedly. They gather around, and Henryk gives the radio set a firm, determined hit. Father, meanwhile, pours liqueur into glasses, and the family is seated around the dining table, having just finished a meal, the table groaning under the weight of the remains. They all clink their glasses together in a shared moment and drink. A column of German soldiers, led by an officer on horseback, marches steadily into view. On the sidewalk of the street, with its buildings in ruins and smoke still rising into the sky, stand onlookers, including Szpilman and Henryk, as Father cranes his neck to see better. They watch, expressionless and silent, as the Germans march past. Regina is busy opening and closing the window, examining the frame carefully with her fingers, while at the other end of the room, Father sits counting a small stack of notes and coins meticulously. Henryk, deep in thought, and Szpilman, fiddling with his father's violin, are lost in their own worlds. The apartment now has noticeably less furniture, and the once-familiar silver is gone. They all look at the table: it is covered with stains, and the veneer is peeling away at one end until it snaps, revealing the bare wood beneath. They begin to hide their remaining precious possessions. Szpilman stands at the public telephone booth, waiting patiently for someone to finally answer his call. Szpilman and Dorota stroll leisurely along a tree-lined street, surrounded by bombed-out buildings and piles of rubble. She casts admiring, almost lovingly affectionate glances at him as they walk and engage in conversation, and he smiles, touched deeply by her warm attention. She becomes embarrassed, blushes slightly, and starts to laugh, and they find themselves almost helpless with laughter, holding onto each other for support. Amidst their shared laughter, he gently takes her hand and tenderly kisses it. The family is gathered closely around the table, listening intently to Father as he reads aloud from the newspaper, hanging on to every word.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: He turns his head to see an extremely pretty young woman gazing adoringly at him, her eyes fixed on his face, while they are both jostled and shoved by the crowd around them, causing his eyes to light up with surprise and delight. Jurek, determined to stay close, pushes his way in beside them, reaching out to take her arm firmly, and begins to pull Dorota along with him as he fights his way down the stairs, maneuvering through the throng of people. Szpilman struggles to make his way to the main door, pushing against the tide of people, when suddenly another bomb explodes, sending a shockwave through the air and filling it with dust and debris, which quickly obscures his vision and that of everyone else around him. Meanwhile, the Szpilman family is in a state of panic, moving frantically in and out of rooms, hurriedly packing clothes and belongings into open suitcases and a trunk within their comfortable, tastefully furnished bourgeois apartment. The living room is lined with books and paintings, and it boasts a boudoir grand piano, silver platters, and candlesticks, all adding to the sense of a once-peaceful home now in disarray. Szpilman sits by the radio set, his ear pressed close to the speaker, as he tries to tune into a station, while Father, holding a silver-framed photograph, crosses the room to Mother, who is struggling to control her tears. He retreats into his room as she hurries into the kitchen, just as the front door opens and Szpilman enters, looking around in bemusement at the flurry of activity. Mother dashes out of the kitchen and begins to search for something as the others continue to bustle and pack. They gather around the radio set, and Henryk gives it a frustrated hit. Father pours liqueur into glasses, and the family, having just finished a meal, is seated around the dining table, which is laden with the remains of their meal. They all clink their glasses together and take a drink. Outside, a column of German soldiers, led by an officer on horseback, marches into view. On the sidewalk of the street, with its buildings in ruins and smoke still rising, stand onlookers, including Szpilman and Henryk, with Father craning his neck to see. They watch expressionlessly as the Germans march past. Inside, Regina is opening and closing the window, running her fingers along the frame to examine it, while at the other end of the room, Father sits counting a small stack of notes and coins. Henryk is lost in thought, and Szpilman is idly fiddling with his father's violin. The apartment now has noticeably less furniture, and the silver is gone. They all look at the table, which is covered in stains, and notice that the veneer is coming away at one end until it finally snaps, revealing the bare wood beneath. They begin to hide their remaining possessions. Szpilman stands at a public telephone, waiting patiently for someone to answer his call. Later, Szpilman and Dorota stroll along a tree-lined street, surrounded by bombed-out buildings and rubble. As they walk and talk, she flicks admiring, almost loving glances at him, and he responds with a smile, touched by her attention. She becomes embarrassed and starts to laugh, and they both become almost helpless with laughter, holding on to each other for support. Amidst their shared laughter, he gently takes her hand and kisses it. The family is gathered around the table once more, listening intently as Father reads aloud from the newspaper.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: He turns to see an extremely pretty young woman gazing adoringly at him while they are jostled and shoved, and his eyes light up. This scene unfolds in a crowded Warsaw street during World War II, a time of turmoil and chaos for the city. Jurek, a friend known for his quick thinking and loyalty, pushes in beside them and takes her arm, pulling Dorota as he fights his way down the stairs, and he too is carried with the flow into the lobby where debris is everywhere, remnants of a bombed building that once stood tall. Szpilman, a talented pianist whose music once filled concert halls across Europe, fights to get to the main door when another bomb explodes, filling the air with dust and debris, obscuring him and everyone else. The Szpilman family is in panic, coming and going out of rooms, packing clothes and belongings into open suitcases and a trunk in a comfortable, tastefully furnished bourgeois apartment in the heart of Warsaw, the living room lined with books from classic authors, paintings, and boasting a boudoir grand, silver platters, and candlesticks reminiscent of their once prosperous life. Szpilman sits by the radio set, ear to the speaker, trying to tune to a station broadcasting news, crucial for survival, while Father, holding a silver-framed photograph of his parents, crosses to Mother. He goes into his room as she can barely control her tears and hurries into the kitchen just as the front door opens and Szpilman enters, looking around bemused by the activity. Mother dashes out of the kitchen and starts to look as the others continue to bustle and pack. They gather round, and Henryk hits the set, frustrated by the poor reception. Father pours liqueur into glasses, a rare treat signaling their attempts to maintain normalcy, and the family is seated around the dining table, having just finished a meal, the table groaning with the remains of what might be their last proper meal together. They all clink glasses and drink. A column of German soldiers, emblematic of the occupying force, led by an officer on horseback, marches into view. On the sidewalk of the street, with its buildings in ruins and smoke still rising, stand onlookers, including Szpilman and Henryk, with Father craning to see, struggling to understand the new realities. They watch expressionless as the Germans march past, a scene replicated in cities across Europe. Regina is opening and closing the window, examining the frame with her fingers, perhaps checking for damage or signs of weakness, while at the other end, Father sits counting a small stack of notes and coins, worried about the family's dwindling resources. Henryk is deep in thought, contemplating their uncertain future, and Szpilman is fiddling with his father's violin, a cherished family heirloom symbolizing their cultural heritage. The apartment has less furniture now and the silver is gone, no doubt sold or traded for necessities. They all look at the table: it's covered in stains, and the veneer is coming away at one end until it snaps, revealing bare wood beneath, a metaphor for their stripped lives. They start to hide the things, an act of desperation and survival against the backdrop of war. Szpilman is on the public telephone, waiting for someone to answer his call, a connection to the outside world that grows more tenuous each day. Szpilman and Dorota stroll along a tree-lined street with bombed-out buildings and rubble, remnants of the relentless air raids. She flicks admiring, almost loving glances at him as they walk and talk, and he is smiling, touched by her, finding solace in human connection amidst chaos. She's embarrassed and begins to laugh, and they become almost helpless, holding on to each other, a moment of joy in dark times. Amidst their laughter, he takes her hand and kisses it, a gesture of affection that defies the surrounding desolation. The family is gathered around the table, listening to Father reading from the newspaper, one of their last ties to the outside world and the grim news it carries.

A column of German soldiers led by an officer on horseback marches into view. On the sidewalk of the street with its buildings in ruins and smoke still rising. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. In a futuristic space station orbiting a distant planet an intrepid crew confronts bizarre alien phenomena and an enigmatic interstellar threat pushing the limits of human endurance. Amidst the chaos of a raging civil war a compassionate medic races through bombedout streets. his every desperate step a race against time to save lives in the midst of utter devastation. On a sundappled afternoon in a quaint European village an eccentric inventor unveils a groundbreaking contraption that defies conventional physics igniting wonder and skepticism in equal measure. stand onlookers including Szpilman and Henryk with Father craning to see. They watch expressionless as the Germans march past. Regina is opening and closing the window examining the frame with her fingers while at the other end Father sits counting a small stack of notes and coins. Henryk is deep in thought and Szpilman is fiddling with his father's violin. The apartment has less furniture now and the silver is gone. They all look at the table. it is covered in stains and the veneer is coming away at one end until it snaps revealing bare wood beneath. They start to hide the things. Szpilman is on the public telephone waiting for someone to answer his call. Szpilman and Dorota stroll along a treelined street with bombedout buildings and rubble. She flicks admiring almost loving glances at him as they walk and talk and he is smiling touched by her. She is embarrassed and begins to laugh and they become almost helpless holding on to each other. Amidst their laughter he takes her hand and kisses it. The family is gathered around the table listening to Father reading from the newspaper.

test_cases.description: He turns to see an extremely pretty young woman gazing adoringly at him while they are jostled and shoved and his eyes light up. Jurek pushes in beside them and takes her arm pulling Dorota as he fights his way down the stairs and he too is carried with the flow into the lobby where debris is everywhere. Szpilman fights to get to the main door when another bomb explodes filling the air with dust and debris obscuring him and everyone else. The Szpilman family is in panic coming and going out of rooms packing clothes and belongings into open suitcases and a trunk in a comfortable tastefully furnished bourgeois apartment. the living room lined with books paintings and boasting a boudoir grand silver platters and candlesticks. Szpilman sits by the radio set ear to the speaker trying to tune to a station while Father holding a silverframed photograph crosses to Mother. He goes into his room as she can barely control her tears and hurries into the kitchen just as the front door opens and Szpilman enters looking around bemused by the activity. They start to hide the things. Szpilman is on the public telephone waiting for someone to answer his call. Szpilman and Dorota stroll along a treelined street with bombedout buildings and rubble. She flicks admiring almost loving glances at him as they walk and talk and he is smiling touched by her. She is embarrassed and begins to laugh and they become almost helpless holding on to each other. Amidst their laughter he takes her hand and kisses it. The family is gathered around the table listening to Father reading from the newspaper.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The cat pivots to notice a remarkably vibrant young tree staring lovingly at it while they are juggled and bounced, and its whiskers brighten. Miro slides in beside those and grabs its branch, dragging Zofia as she crawls her path up the ladder, and she too is swept with the wave into the courtyard where confetti is nowhere. Tock scrambles to reach the side gate when another balloon implodes, filling the sky with feathers and cotton, disguising her and everyone nearby. The Tock clan is in jubilation, arriving and departing from parks, collecting shoes and trinkets into closed barrels and a vase in a disorganized, flamboyantly adorned minimalist gallery, the gallery lined with guitars, sculptures, and flaunting a recliner grand, copper bowls, and teacups. Tock lounges by the television set, nose to the display, attempting to switch to a channel, while Uncle, grasping a golden-framed comic, saunters to Aunt. He marches into his chamber as she can barely suppress her giggles and scampers into the pantry just as the back window opens and Tock exits, gazing around amused by the chaos. Aunt hustles out of the pantry and begins to wander as the others persist in lounging and unpacking. They cluster near, and Marcus taps the screen. Uncle pours water into mugs, and the clan is perched around the kitchen island, having just started a feast, the island sighing with the beginnings. They all tap mugs and sip. A parade of Italian fishermen, guided by a philosopher on a tricycle, glides into view. On the rooftop of the factory, with its chimneys in harmony and smoke barely drifting, stand spectators, including Tock and Marcus, with Uncle peeking to watch. They observe blankly as the Italians glide forth. Sasha is shutting and unlatching the curtain, testing the clasp with her toes, while at the other end, Uncle perches tallying a stack of pebbles and shells. Marcus is lost in imagination, and Tock is adjusting his uncle's saxophone. The gallery has more sculptures now and the copper is present. They all gaze at the island: it's covered in crumbs, and the polish is peeling at one corner until it cracks, exposing fresh metal beneath. They commence to display the stuff. Tock is on the public bench, hoping for someone to hear his shout. Tock and Zofia glide along a pebble-lined path with glittering buildings and flowers. She flicks amazed, almost adoring glances at it as they stand and whisper, and it is giggling, moved by her. She's flustered and starts to smile, and they become almost buoyant, hanging on to each other. Amidst their giggles, it takes her muzzle and licks it. The clan is scattered around the island, tuning to Uncle murmuring from the brochure.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Szpilman notices a young woman named Dorota gazing at him amidst a chaotic crowd. Jurek pulls her to safety through debris-filled surroundings as Szpilman tries reaching the main exit during a bombing. At home, Szpilman's family hastily packs belongings in their well-furnished apartment, filled with books and art. Szpilman struggles to tune into a radio station while his mother fights tears. Returning home, Szpilman is puzzled by the packing activity around him. The family gathers for a meal, drinking together as German soldiers march outside. Szpilman, Henryk, and their father watch expressionlessly. Regina inspects windows, and Father counts money as their apartment becomes sparser, with furniture and silver missing. Szpilman uses a public phone, awaiting an answer. He and Dorota walk along rubble-strewn streets, exchanging affectionate glances and laughter, culminating in a hand-kiss. The family listens to Father read the newspaper around the table.
